Bill Gates: “Oggi usereste Windows Mobile anziché Android, se non fosse stato per l’antitrust”
07 Nov 2019, 11:35 by Nicola Ligas
Forse ricorderete un’intervista a Bill Gates di pochi mesi fa, nella quale il papà di Microsoft ammise che uno dei suoi più grandi rimpianti è quello di aver permesso ad Android, e quindi a Google, di diventare l’unica vera alternativa ad iOS; uno sbaglio che Gates stesso stimava in 400 miliardi di dollari. Si tratta di un’ammissione non da poco, che però adesso viene un attimo corretta.
Gates ha infatti recentemente affermato che, se non fosse stato “distratto” da una causa di antitrust in corso all’epoca da parte del Dipartimento della Giustizia USA, le cose sarebbero andate diversamente.
There’s no doubt that the antitrust lawsuit was bad for Microsoft, and we would have been more focused on creating the phone operating system and so instead of using Android today you would be using Windows Mobile. If it hadn’t been for the antitrust case… we were so close, I was just too distracted. I screwed that up because of the distraction.Bill Gates
“Oggi usereste Windows Mobile anziché Android“. Gates si dimostra sicuro del fatto suo, eppure fu Microsoft stessa a passare da Windows Mobile a Windows Phone, dando al contempo l’opportunità ad Android di avanzare indisturbato, mentre l’azienda di Redmond riorganizzava la sua strategia mobile.
La ragione di cotanta confidenza da parte di Bill Gates potrebbe risiedere in Motorola. “Eravamo solo tre mesi in ritardo su una release che Motorola avrebbe usato in uno smartphone“. Non è ben chiaro a cosa si riferisca, perché questo fantomatico dispositivo non l’abbiamo mai visto, ma una decina di anni fa Motorola lanciò proprio la serie Droid, che dette un grande impulso alla diffusione di Android negli USA. Probabilmente Gates avrebbe sperato di vedere Windows al suo posto, anche perché si tratta di un mercato in cui il vincitore prende tutto, e non c’è più spazio per gli sconfitti; questo l’ha ribadito nuovamente (“so yes it’s a winner takes all game”).
Col senno di poi è chiaro che Microsoft abbia perso una grande chance, anche se, sinceramente, dare la colpa a fattori esterni non rende molto onore a Bill Gates stesso. Ogni azienda avrà i suoi problemi, in qualsiasi momento e per qualsiasi ragione, ma è proprio il non lasciare che questi distolgano l’attenzione dall’obiettivo primario a fare la differenza. E la Microsoft di oggi è davvero diversa da quella dell’epoca, al punto che oggi è lei stessa ad abbracciare Android, ammettendo al contempo la sconfitta, ma anche il fatto che dai problemi possono sempre nascere nuove opportunità. A patto di non intestardirsi.



Via: The Verge

Bill Gates: "Today you would use Windows Mobile instead of Android, if it wasn't for antitrust"
07 Nov 2019, 11:35 by Nicola Ligas
Perhaps you will remember an interview with Bill Gates a few months ago, in which Microsoft's dad admitted that one of his biggest regrets is that he allowed Android, and therefore Google, to become the only real alternative to iOS; a mistake that Gates himself estimated at 400 billion dollars. This is an admission not just, but now it is a correct moment.
Gates recently said that if he had not been "distracted" by an antitrust case pending at the time by the US Department of Justice, things would have been different.
There are no doubt that the antitrust lawsuit was bad for Microsoft, and we would have been more focused on creating the operating system and so instead of using Android today would be using Windows Mobile. We were so close, I was just too distracted. I screwed that up because of the distraction.Bill Gates
"Today you would use Windows Mobile instead of Android". Gates is sure of his business, yet it was Microsoft itself that switched from Windows Mobile to Windows Phone, while giving Android the opportunity to move forward undisturbed, while the Redmond company reorganized its mobile strategy.
The reason for such great confidence on the part of Bill Gates may lie with Motorola. "We were only three months behind a release that Motorola would use in a smartphone." It is not clear what he is referring to, because this phantom device we have never seen, but a decade ago Motorola launched the Droid series, which gave a big boost to the spread of Android in the US. Probably Gates would have hoped to see Windows in its place, also because it is a market in which the winner takes everything, and there is no more room for the losers; this reaffirmed it again ("so yes it’s a winner takes all game").
In hindsight it is clear that Microsoft has lost a great chance, even if, frankly, blaming external factors does not give much credit to Bill Gates himself. Every company will have its problems, at any time and for any reason, but it is precisely not letting them divert attention from the primary objective to make a difference. And the Microsoft of today is really different from that of the era, to the point that today it is itself to embrace Android, admitting defeat at the same time, but also the fact that new problems can always arise from problems. On condition that you do not become stubborn.



Via: The Verge
